title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
JPMorgan Chase has elevated two potential successors to chief executive Jamie Dimon in a reshuffle of its top ranks.

The US bank promoted Marianne Lake, 51, and Jennifer Piepszak, 51, to co-heads of its biggest division, the consumer and community banking unit which generated $51.3bn in revenue last year and has more than 120,000 employees.

Dimon, who is 65 and underwent emergency heart surgery last year, has led the bank since 2006. The JPMorgan board has said it would like Dimon to stay a “significant number of additional years”.

Gordon Smith, 62, currently co-president and co-chief operating officer and head of the CCB unit, will step down from his roles at the end of the year.

Jeremy Barnum, 48, currently head of global research for JPMorgan's corporate and investment bank, will succeed Piepszak as finance chief.

Go deeper: US banking editor Joshua Franklin talks to the FT's News Briefing podcast presenter Marc Filippino about the reshuffle at the top of JPMorgan Chase and what it means for Jamie Dimon. Listen here.

Coronavirus digest

  • The EU has sought to take the initiative on the vexed topic of Covid-19 vaccine patents by suggesting World Trade Organization members should use existing rules to make it easier to share intellectual property.

  • A study has found that the Oxford/AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine works well as a third booster shot, despite concern that the immune system might fight off the adenovirus the jab uses as a delivery mechanism.

  • High-frequency data indicators have offered evidence that the eurozone will log a strong second-quarter rebound from its double-dip recession. France celebrated a reopening of café and restaurant terraces on Wednesday as the country further eased its six-month Covid-19 lockdown.

  • India reported more than 4,500 Covid-19 deaths on Tuesday, the highest known single-day tally of any country during the pandemic. The Serum Institute of India plans to extend its halt on Covid-19 vaccine exports.

  • One of Taiwan's few remaining allies has warned that it may be forced to switch diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing to gain access to Chinese coronavirus vaccines.

Follow the latest on our live blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter.

In the news

Israel continues assault on Gaza Israeli warplanes struck multiple targets in Gaza overnight as Israel kept up its assault on Palestinian militants despite growing international calls for a ceasefire to end the nine-day conflict. In the US, Joe Biden met progressive Democratic congresswoman Rashida Tlaib on Tuesday as he comes under growing pressure from within his party to do more to stop the hostilities.

Rudy Giuliani's son launches campaign for New York governor Andrew Giuliani, the son of former New York mayor Rudy Giuliani and a political descendant of former US president Donald Trump, on Tuesday formally declared his candidacy to become governor of New York state. Giuliani, 35, will seek to unseat Andrew Cuomo, 63, a three-term Democrat and son of another three-term governor.

  • New York attorney-general Letitia James is joining the Manhattan district attorney's office in a criminal investigation of the Trump organisation, it was announced on Tuesday. (CNN)

Bitcoin falls sharply after China signals crypto crackdown Bitcoin tumbled 14 per cent to its lowest level since early February after Chinese regulators intensified efforts to crack down on the use of cryptocurrencies by financial institutions. For more markets news sign up to our new email Unhedged.

Yellen urges US companies to embrace Biden infrastructure plan In a speech at the US Chamber of Commerce on Tuesday Janet Yellen called on top US executives to embrace Joe Biden's sweeping infrastructure bill as negotiations between the White House and Republicans on Capitol Hill over a compromise deal heat up.

Silicon Valley veteran warns of ‘very frothy' markets Sandy Robertson, best known for helping to start Robertson Stephens and Montgomery Securities, two investment banks that dominated technology underwriting in the 1990s, told the Financial Times “we are in a very frothy period”. 

Firm founded by son of China's finance tsar invests in tech A fund founded by the son of China's vice-premier Liu He has invested heavily in tech companies, including units of leading internet groups Tencent and JD.com. The firm, which has $1.6bn of assets under management, was established in late 2016, according to corporate records seen by the Financial Times.

Retailers boost forecasts as customers go on shopping spree Walmart, the largest retailer in the world, boosted its financial outlook for the remainder of the year after recording the strongest first-quarter sales in its history. Department store Macy's also raised its annual guidance and the DIY chain Home Depot reported record first-quarter revenues after a pandemic-fuelled boom in home improvement.

Google launches AI health tool for skin conditions The tech company is taking one of its most significant steps into healthcare, launching an AI-powered tool, called Derm Assist, that will help consumers self-diagnose hundreds of skin conditions ranging from acne to melanoma.

The day ahead

Fed minutes The US central bank publishes the minutes of its April meeting today in the wake of last week's inflation leap. Chair Jay Powell reiterated after policymakers' last meeting that the Federal Reserve was still “a long way” from withdrawing monetary support.

Earnings Target, Lowe's and TJX, owner of TJ Maxx, Marshalls, and HomeGoods, are the latest retailers to report. Network equipment provider Cisco releases earnings after the market closes.

Oatly IPO The US stock market debut of the Swedish oat milk producer, which prices its initial public offering today, marks a milestone for the company's evangelist-in-chief Toni Petersson.

Over two days the Business of Luxury Summit will host creatives, executives and analysts from across the globe to talk about how they are navigating the impact of Covid-19. Gain critical insight by registering here.

What else we're reading

There are reasons to worry about US inflation When inflation starts to rise, special factors can always explain it. But in truth, the big reasons for concern are not what is happening right now, but rather the political forces at work, writes Martin Wolf.

  • Lawrence Summers, the former US Treasury secretary, speaking at a conference on Tuesday, sharply rebuked the Fed for loose monetary policies, accusing it of creating a “dangerous complacency” in markets and misreading the economy.

America's urban crime wave threatens Biden Murders in New York rose last year by 43 per cent — and are on track to be higher this year than last. The situation is even uglier in Chicago. Ditto across urban America. It would be unfair to blame Joe Biden for any of this. Yet as president — and leader of the party that controls most big US cities — he will pay a price if it goes on, argues Edward Luce.

Huarong's woes are a warning to lazy investors Irreverent overseas analysts have dubbed it “Hua-wrong”. But the problems besetting China Huarong Asset Management, the country's largest distressed debt investor, are deadly serious. Beijing may be tempted to shunt all or most losses on to overseas investors, writes Brooke Masters, and that's why Huarong's fate is arousing such great interest. 

Challenging China: Britain after Brexit In the aftermath of the 2016 referendum, UK ministers talked optimistically about negotiating a trade deal with Beijing. But newly free from Brussels, Downing Street is keen to reinforce political and military ties with the US as Washington girds itself for what analysts have described as a new cold war with Beijing.

US telecoms decide focusing on pipes isn't so dumb after all John Stankey, AT&T's chief executive, was crowing last month about the success of monster movie Godzilla vs Kong at both the box office and in driving audiences to the HBO Max streaming platform, the group's attempt to challenge Netflix. This week, he sounded more like a traditional telecoms executive after unveiling plans to spin out and merge WarnerMedia.

The 50 greatest food stores in the world Where to find the best produce on the planet, from classic New York delis and Indian spice emporiums to German sausage shops, How To Spend It has a comprehensive guide.

Tod's chief executive Diego Della Valle plans for the future The founder and chief executive of Tod's tells FT editor Roula Khalaf at the Business of Luxury Summit that he would only ever consider a sale of the Italian luxury goods maker to LVMH.
